sections.title: Opacity Readings on Fugitive Emission Sources

content.text: Fugitive emissions are observed using EPA Method 9 in a manner similar to reading point-source emissions. However, because fugitive emissions are not concentrated at a single point, there are additional steps the observer must take to ensure accurate opacity readings.

sections.title: How to Read Opacity of Fugitive Emissions

content.text:
• Similar to point-source emissions, the observer should take readings at the point of greatest opacity in the plume, ensuring the view is perpendicular to the plume's direction. The sun should remain within a 140° sector behind the observer.

• Fugitive emissions can interfere with each other, especially in busy or dusty environments. The observer should make every effort to isolate the emissions from the source being observed.

• Fugitive emissions are sensitive to small changes in wind direction and speed. The observer should be prepared to reposition quickly if the emissions shift direction.
